page.title: 17BIRD LIFE ON THE LUGG FLATS
page.content: The Lugg Flats lie below the 50 metre contour and due to the seasonal flooding of the River Lugg, consist of very fertile natural grassland. The Lugg Flats or "Meadows", as they are sometimes known, are very attractive to birds. In winter there are Lapwings and migrants such as Redwings and Fieldfare and during flooding, Mallards, Teel, Wigeon, Mute Swan, Snipe, and gulls galore, feed in the area. The gulls are mainly of the Lesser Black Back variety and they make a daily excursion from the Severn Estuary up the course of the River Wye to return, during the evening, as light fades. During the dry summer months bird life is scarce apart from the occasional scavenging Rook and Carrion Crow and flocks of Starlings.
